(แม่สาย) is the northernmost city of
. It is mainly a stepping stone for visits to
and has few attractions of its own.

.  Buses from Chiang Rai are very frequent (every 10-15 min), cost 40 baht (one way) and take about 1.5 hours, while buses from Chiang Mai take about 4 hours (210 baht one way).  All public buses terminate at a bus station well south of Mae Sai, so you have to continue onward to the city proper with
songthaews waiting outside (20 baht per passenger fixed fare).  The
, on the other hand, leave from a stand in the city centre a few hundred metres down the street from the border. The last blue songthaew that departs for

leaves at 14:00.

There are day-tours taking visitors to Mae Sai, the
, and a couple of other places to see on the way as well. Tourist minibuses are more expensive (around 800 baht for a day tour from

including lunch) and, if fully loaded (but this is not always the case), are much less comfortable. However, this is still an option worth considering, if you want to combine your visa run with a sightseeing tour through Chiang Rai Province.
Mae Sai is a one-street town and the centre is easily covered on foot.

value: Burmese temple at Wat Phra That Wai Dao

There's really only one place to visit in Mae Sai, but many visitors breeze past it on their way to Myanmar.

value: directions=before Immigration, turn left and go through covered bazaar

content=Built on a small hill up a steep staircase, overlooking Mae Sai and Tachileik, this temple and its stupa are unremarkable, but there are a few interesting monuments around it.  Next to the stupa is a small
that gives a nice taste of what awaits on the other side.  Towards the river is a multistoried
, a Lanna king famous for beating back several Burmese invasions and dispatching the Burmese crown prince in a duel, and just in case the message of this isn't clear enough, there's also a
The gate marking the northernmost point of Thailand

ท่าขี้เหล็ก). An entry permit valid for up to 14 days costs 500 baht or USD17. Travellers using this option are given a paper entry permit and their passports are held at the immigration office until they return to Thailand. Stop at the entry point and talk with the Thai officials  to organise this. It is easily done. In the Tachilek market just over the border, expect to be assaulted by any number of persons offering cheap cigarettes and Viagra/Cialis. From here, you can travel as far as

), 160 km away, but to travel to the rest of Myanmar, a visa in advance is needed. Transit travellers can arrange for a visa and can have their passport sent to their port of exit. Some local NGOs are worth visiting to see some of their humanitarian work.
Covered bazaar leading to Wat Phra That Doi Wao

There are plenty of small shops lining both sides of the street leading to the border crossing that sell:

directions=On a hillside, on a road that runs parallel to, and is about 1 km west of, the main Pahonyothin Rd

content=This pleasant restaurant is probably the classiest in town. The views down the narrow valley are stunning with the Shwedegon chedi across the border in Myanmar lighted at night. The smoked duck curry is delicious. Service can be slow but this is not a restaurant for those in a hurry.
directions=About 1 km up from the border on the right as you walk in that direction

There are several comfortable coffee shops on the main road leading to the immigration checkpoint.

value: directions=On the main road about a 10 min walk from the border

content=Standard Thai hotel with clean well-presented rooms containing all the usual amenities of a hotel in this class. The loud maid phones on each floor which resonate down the corridor may put some off. Ask for a room at the opposite end of the corridor.
directions=On the same road as the old King Kobra Hotel
content=This hotel is probably the best of the lot. From the 3rd floor you have a view into Myanmar and the Sai River.
